Gradient Statistics Aware Power Control for Over-the-Air Federated Learning

Naifu Zhang and Meixia Tao N. Zhang and M. Tao are with the Department of Electronic Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, P. R. China. (email: arthaslery@sjtu.edu.cn; mxtao@sjtu.edu.cn.). Part of this work is presented at IEEE ICC 2020 workshop [1]
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a promising technique that enables many edge devices to train a machine learning model collaboratively in wireless networks. By exploiting the superposition nature of wireless waveforms, over-the-air computation (AirComp) can accelerate model aggregation and hence facilitate communication-efficient FL. Due to channel fading, power control is crucial in AirComp. Prior works assume that the signals to be aggregated from each device, i.e., local gradients have identical statistics. In FL, however, gradient statistics vary over both training iterations and feature dimensions, and are unknown in advance. This paper studies the power control problem for over-the-air FL by taking gradient statistics into account. The goal is to minimize the aggregation error by optimizing the transmit power at each device subject to peak power constraints. We obtain the optimal policy in closed form when gradient statistics are given. Notably, we show that the optimal transmit power is continuous and monotonically decreases with the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of gradient vectors. We then propose a method to estimate gradient statistics with negligible communication cost. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed gradient-statistics-aware power control achieves higher test accuracy than the existing schemes for a wide range of scenarios.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, over-the-air computation, power control, fading channel.

I Introduction

The proliferation of mobile devices such as smartphones, tablets, and wearable devices has revolutionized people’s daily lives. Due to the growing computation and sensing capabilities of these devices, a wealth of data has been generated each day. This has promoted a wide range of artificial intelligence (AI) applications such as image recognition and natural language processing. Traditional machine learning procedures, including both training and inference, are carried out through cloud computing on a centralized data center that has full access to the entire data set. Wireless edge devices are thus required to upload their collected raw data to the center, which can be very costly in terms of energy and bandwidth consumption, and unfavorable due to response delay and privacy concerns. It is thus increasingly desired to let edge devices engage in the learning process by keeping the raw data locally and performing training/inference either collaboratively or individually. This emerging technology is known as Edge Machine Learning [2] or Edge Intelligence [3].

Federated learning (FL)[4, 5, 6, 7] is a new edge learning framework that enables many edge devices to collaboratively train a machine learning model without exchanging datasets under the coordination of an edge server in wireless networks. Compared with traditional learning at a centralized data center, FL offers several distinct advantages, such as preserving privacy, reducing network congestion, and leveraging distributed on-device computation. In FL, each edge device downloads a shared model from the edge server, computes an update to the current model by learning from its local dataset, then sends this update to the edge server. Therein, the updates are averaged to improve the shared model. FL has recently attracted significant attention from both academia and industry, such as [8, 9, 10, 11].

The main bottleneck in FL is the communication cost since a large number of participating edge devices send their updates to the edge server at each round of the model training. Existing methods to obtain communication-efficient FL can be mainly divided into three categories: model parameter compression [12, 13], gradient sparsification [14, 15], and infrequent local update [4, 16]. Nevertheless, the communication cost of FL is still proportional to the number of edge devices, and thus inefficient in large-scale environment. Recently, a fast model aggregation approach is proposed for synchronous FL by applying the over-the-air computation (AirComp) principle [17], such as in [18, 19, 20, 21]. This is accomplished by exploiting the waveform superposition nature of the wireless medium to compute the desired function of the distributed local gradients (i.e., the weighted average function) by concurrent transmission. Such AirComp-based FL, referred to as over-the-air FL in this work, can dramatically save the uplink communication bandwidth.

Due to the channel fading, device selection and power control are crucial to achieve a reliable and high-performance over-the-air FL. In [22], the authors jointly optimize the transmit power at edge devices and the receive scaling factor (known as denoising factor) at the edge server for minimizing the mean square error (MSE) of the aggregated signal. It is shown that the optimal transmit power in static channels exhibits a threshold-based structure. Namely, each device applies channel-inversion power control if its quality indicator exceeds the optimal threshold, and applies full power transmission otherwise. The work [22], however, is purely for AirComp-based signal aggregation (not in the context of learning), where the signal on each device is assumed to be independent and identically distributed (IID) with zero mean and unit variance. For AirComp-based gradient aggregation in FL, the work [19] introduces a truncation-based approach for excluding the edge devices with deep fading channels to strike a good balance between learning performance and aggregation error. The work [18] proposes a joint device selection and receiver beamforming design method to find the maximum number of selected devices with MSE requirements to improve the learning performance. As in [22], it is assumed in both [18] and [19] that the signal (i.e., the local gradient) to be aggregated from each device is IID, and normalized with zero mean and unit variance. By exploiting the sparsity pattern in gradient vectors, the work [21] projects the gradient estimate in each device into a low-dimensional vector and transmits only the important gradient entries while accumulating the error from previous iterations. Therein, a channel-inversion like power control scheme, similar to those in [22, 19, 18] is designed so that the gradient vectors sent from the selected devices are aligned at the edge server.

Note that all the exiting works on power control for over-the-air FL have overlooked the following statistical characteristics of gradients: the gradient distribution over training iterations is not necessarily identical; and even in the same iteration, the distribution of each entry of the gradient vector can be non-identical. A general observation is that the gradient distribution changes over iterations and is different in each feature dimension. In addition, if the gradient distribution is unknown for each device, normalizing the gradient to a distribution with zero mean and unit variance is infeasible. As such, due to the neglect of the above characteristics of gradient distribution, the existing power control methods for over-the-air FL may not perform efficiently in practice.

Motivated by the above issue, in this paper, we study the optimal power control problem for over-the-air FL in fading channels by taking gradient statistics into account. Our goal is to minimize the MSE of the aggregated model at each iteration, and hence improve the accuracy of FL, by jointly optimizing the transmit power at each device and the denoising factor at the edge server given the first-order and second-order statistics of gradients. The main contributions of this work are outlined below:

  • •

    Optimal power control with known gradient statistics: We first derive the MSE expression of gradient aggregation at each iteration of the model training when the first-order and second-order statistics of the gradient vectors are known. We then formulate a joint optimization problem of transmit power at edge devices and denoising factor at the edge server for MSE minimization subject to individual peak power constraints at edge devices. By decomposing this non-convex problem into subproblems defined on different subregions, we obtain the optimal power control strategy in closed form. Unlike the existing threshold-based power control for normalized signal in [22], our optimal transmit power depends not only on the channel quality and noise power, but also heavily on the gradient statistics. In particular, we find that the relative dispersion of the gradient values, i.e., the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of the gradient vectors, plays a key role in the optimal transmit power control. Specifically, we prove that the optimal transmit power of each device is a continuous and monotonically decreasing function of the gradient SMCV.

  • •

    Optimal power control in special cases: In the special case where the gradient SMCV approaches infinity, which could happen when the model training converges and/or the dataset is highly non-IID, we show that there is an optimal threshold for the device aggregation capability, below which the device transmits with full power and above which it transmits at the power to equalize the weight of its gradient for aggregation to one. In the other special case where the gradient SMCV approaches zero, which could happen when the model training just begins, we show that the optimal power control is to let all the devices transmit with their peak powers.

  • •

    Adaptive power control with unknown gradient statistics: We propose an adaptive power control algorithm that estimates the gradient statistics based on the historical aggregated gradients and then dynamically adjusts the power values in each iteration based on the estimation results. The communication cost consumed by estimating the gradient statistics is negligible compared to the transmission of the entire gradient vector.

To evaluate the efficiency of the proposed power control scheme, we implement the FL in PyTorch for AI applications of three datasets: MNIST, CIFAR-10 and SVHN. Experimental results demonstrate that the over-the-air FL with the proposed adaptive power control obtains higher model accuracy than the considered existing power control methods (full power transmission and threshold-based power control for normalized signal [22]). In particular, while the full power transmission performs poorly in high signal-noise ratio (SNR) region and non-IID data distribution and the threshold-based power control for normalized signal [22] performs poorly in low SNR region and IID data distribution, the proposed power control can perform very well over a wide range of scenarios by exploiting the gradient statistics.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The over-the-air FL system is modeled in Section II. Section III describes the optimal power control strategy with known gradient statistics. In Section IV, we introduce an adaptive power control scheme when the gradient statistics are unknown in advance. Section V provides experimental results. Finally we conclude the paper in Section VI.

II System Model

II-B Over-the-Air Computation for Gradient Aggregation

Let 𝒈k​(t)≜∇Lk,tS​G​D​(𝒘​(t))∈ℝD≜subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑘𝑡𝑆𝐺𝐷𝒘𝑡superscriptℝ𝐷\bm{g}_{k}(t)\triangleq\nabla L_{k,t}^{SGD}(\bm{w}(t))\in\mathbb{R}^{D} denote the gradient vector computed on device k𝑘k at iteration t𝑡t. The following are key assumptions on the distribution of each entry gk,d​(t),d∈{1,…,D}subscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡𝑑1…𝐷g_{k,d}(t),d\in\{1,...,D\} of 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t):

  • •

    The gradient elements {gk,d​(t)},∀k∈𝒦subscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦\{g_{k,d}(t)\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, are independent and identically distributed over devices k𝑘k’s. Note that the local datasets are typically non-IID across devices in federated learning. However, due to privacy concerns, their actual distributions are usually unknown to the edge server, whether being identical or non-identical. As such and, by default, the distributions of the local gradients {gk,d​(t)}subscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡\{g_{k,d}(t)\} trained from these local datasets are treated equally across devices from the edge server’s perspective.

  • •

    The gradient elements {gk,d​(t)},∀t∈ℕsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡for-all𝑡ℕ\{g_{k,d}(t)\},\forall t\in\mathbb{N}, are non-identically distributed over iterations t𝑡t’s. In other words, the gradient distribution is non-stationary over time. The non-stationary distribution is valid since the gradient values in general change rapidly at the beginning, then gradually approach to zero as the training goes on.

  • •

    The gradient elements {gk,d​(t)},∀d∈{1,2,…,D}subscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡for-all𝑑12…𝐷\{g_{k,d}(t)\},\forall d\in\{1,2,...,D\}, are independent but non-identically distributed over gradient vector dimension d𝑑d’s. This assumption is valid as long as the features in a data sample are independent but non-identically distributed, which is typically the case.

The gradient of interest at the edge server at each iteration t𝑡t is given by

𝒈​(t)=1K​∑k∈𝒦𝒈k​(t).𝒈𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}(t)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\bm{g}_{k}(t)}. (3)

To obtain (3), all the devices transmit their gradient vectors 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t) concurrently in an analog manner, following the AirComp principle as shown in Fig. 1. We consider block fading channels, where the channel coefficients remain unchanged within the duration of each iteration in FL but may change independently from one iteration to another. We define the duration of one iteration as one time block, indexed by t∈ℕ𝑡ℕt\in\mathbb{N}. For simplicity, each edge device and the edge server are equipped with a single antenna. Let hk​(t)subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k}(t) denote the complex-valued channel coefficient from device k𝑘k to the edge server at the t𝑡t-th time block. It is assumed to be generated from a stationary and ergodic process. Each transmission block takes a duration of D𝐷D slots, one slot for one entry in the D𝐷D-dimensional gradient vector. Each gradient vector 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t) is multiplied with a pre-processing factor, denoted as bk​(t)subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡b_{k}(t). The received signal vector at the edge server is given by

where 𝒏​(t)𝒏𝑡\bm{n}(t) denotes the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) vector at the edge server with each element having zero mean and variance of σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\sigma_{n}^{2}. Let pk​(t)≥0subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡0p_{k}(t)\geq 0 denote the transmit power of device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} at time block t𝑡t. To compensate the channel phase offset and scale the actual signal amplitude at each device, we design the pre-processing factor as bk​(t)=pk​(t)αk​(t)​e−j​θk​(t)subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡b_{k}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{p_{k}(t)}{\alpha_{k}(t)}}e^{-j\theta_{k}(t)}, where θk​(t)subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}(t) is the phase of hk​(t)subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k}(t) and αk​(t)≜𝔼​[‖𝒈k​(t)‖2]≜subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡2\alpha_{k}(t)\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}_{k}(t)\|^{2}] is the mean squared norm of the gradient of device k𝑘k. Here, we have assumed that each device k𝑘k can estimate perfectly its own channel phase θk​(t)subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}(t). The mean squared norm of gradient, αk​(t)subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡\alpha_{k}(t) can be estimated with negligible communication costs as we shall present in Section IV. To design the optimal power control policy pk​(t)subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k}(t), for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, we also assume that the edge server knows the channel amplitude |hk|subscriptℎ𝑘|h_{k}| of all devices. By such design of bk​(t)subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡b_{k}(t), we can rewrite (4) as

𝒚​(t)=∑k∈𝒦pk​(t)αk​(t)​|hk​(t)|​𝒈k​(t)+𝒏​(t).𝒚𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝒏𝑡\bm{y}(t)=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\sqrt{\frac{p_{k}(t)}{\alpha_{k}(t)}}|h_{k}(t)|\bm{g}_{k}(t)}+\bm{n}(t). (5)

Each device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} has a peak power budget Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k}, i.e.,

pk​(t)≤Pk,∀k∈𝒦,∀t∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑃𝑘formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡ℕp_{k}(t)\leq P_{k},\quad\forall{k}\in\mathcal{K},\forall t\in\mathbb{N}. (6)

Upon receiving 𝒚​(t)𝒚𝑡\bm{y}(t), the edge server applies a denoising factor, denoted by η​(t)𝜂𝑡\eta(t), to recover the gradient of interest as

where the factor 1/K1𝐾1/K is employed for the averaging purpose.

II-C Performance Measure

We are interested in minimizing the distortion of the recovered gradient 𝒈^​(t)bold-^𝒈𝑡\bm{\hat{g}}(t) with respect to (w.r.t.) the ground true gradient 𝒈​(t)𝒈𝑡\bm{g}(t) at each iteration t𝑡t. The distortion is measured by the instantaneous MSE defined as

where the expectation is over the distribution of the transmitted gradients 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t) and the received noise 𝒏​(t)𝒏𝑡\bm{n}(t), md​(t)subscript𝑚𝑑𝑡m_{d}(t) and σd2​(t)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡\sigma_{d}^{2}(t) denote the mean (first-order statistics) and variance (second-order statistics) of the d𝑑d-th entry of gradient 𝒈​(t)𝒈𝑡\bm{g}(t) at iteration t𝑡t, respectively. Note that in deriving (8), we have used the previous assumption that the gradient elements {gk,d​(t)},∀k∈𝒦subscript𝑔𝑘𝑑𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦\{g_{k,d}(t)\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, are IID across devices, i.e, αk​(t)=𝔼​[‖𝒈k​(t)‖2]=𝔼​[‖𝒈​(t)‖2]=∑d=1D(σd2​(t)+md2​(t))subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒈𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡\alpha_{k}(t)=\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}_{k}(t)\|^{2}]=\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}(t)\|^{2}]=\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\left(\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)+m_{d}^{2}(t)\right)}.

Observing (8) closely, we find that the MSE consists of three components, representing the individual misalignment error (the first term), the composite misalignment error (the second term), and the noise-induced error (the third term), respectively. The individual misalignment error is weighted by the gradient variance ∑d=1Dσd2​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)} while the composite misalignment error is weighted by the gradient mean ∑d=1Dmd2​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡\sum_{d=1}^{D}{m_{d}^{2}(t)}. In the special case when the gradient has zero mean, the MSE in (8) reduces to that in [22] where the composite misalignment error is absent. Our objective is to minimize MSE in (8), by jointly optimizing the transmit power pk​(t)subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k}(t) at all devices and the denoising factor η​(t)𝜂𝑡\eta(t) at the edge server, subject to the individual power budget in (6) at each iteration t𝑡t.

II-D Gradient Statistics

In general, the individual misalignment error and the composite misalignment error in MSE of the gradient aggregation (8) cannot be forced to zero simultaneously due to the peak power budget on each device. It is difficult to capture the tradeoff between the two errors by directly using their respective weights, namely, the gradient variance and gradient mean. To tackle this issue, we introduce two alternative parameters of gradient statistics in this subsection.

Let α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) denote the mean squared norm (MSN) of 𝒈​(t)𝒈𝑡\bm{g}(t), i.e., 𝔼​[‖𝒈​(t)‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒈𝑡2\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}(t)\|^{2}], which is given by

α​(t)=∑d=1D(σd2​(t)+md2​(t)),𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡\alpha(t)=\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\bigg{(}\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)+m_{d}^{2}(t)\bigg{)}}, (9)

and let β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) denote the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of 𝒈​(t)𝒈𝑡\bm{g}(t), which is given by

β​(t)=∑d=1Dσd2​(t)∑d=1Dmd2​(t).𝛽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡\beta(t)=\frac{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)}}{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{m_{d}^{2}(t)}}. (10)

While α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) measures the average absolute value of the gradient values at iteration t𝑡t, β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) is a measure of relative dispersion of the gradient at iteration t𝑡t. In Section III-B, we shall show that the optimal transmit power is dominated by β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) and independent of α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t). Fig. 2 illustrates the experimental results of the alternative gradient statistics α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) of three datasets, MNIST, CIFAR-10, and SVHN, where the gradients are updated ideally without any transmission error. Both IID and non-IID partitions are considered for the training dataset and the generation of IID and non-IID data distributions is specified in Section V. Each value of α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) is obtained by averaging over 300 model trainings. It is observed that as the training time increases, the gradient MSN α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) gradually decreases and approaches to a constant while the gradient SMCV β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) keeps increasing from a small starting point for all the three datasets. Intuitively, in SGD-based learning, the gradient mean {md​(t)}subscript𝑚𝑑𝑡\{m_{d}(t)\} is large at the begining, then gradually approaches to zero when the model converges; the gradient variance {σd2​(t)}superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡\{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)\}, on the other hand, remains approximately unchanged due to the randomness of local datasets throughout the training process. As a result, according to the definitions in (9) and (10), the absolute squared norm of the gradient, α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t), decreases during the training and converges to a constant , but the relative dispersion of the gradient, β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t), is very small when the training just begins and then gradually increases when the training continues. It is also observed that α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) in non-IID partition are much larger than those in IID partition for all the three datasets. This indicates that the gradient distribution with non-IID dataset partition is more dispersive than that with IID dataset partition as expected. Note that the gradient MSN α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) of CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets are larger than MNIST dataset. This is because the dimensions of model parameters for training CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets are larger than MNIST dataset.

By (9) and (10), the MSE in (8) can be rewritten as (omitting the constant coefficient 1/K21superscript𝐾21/K^{2} for convenience)

MSE​(t)=MSE𝑡absent\displaystyle\text{MSE}(t)= β​(t)​α​(t)β​(t)+1​∑k∈𝒦(pk​(t)​|hk​(t)|η​(t)​α​(t)−1)2𝛽𝑡𝛼𝑡𝛽𝑡1subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝜂𝑡𝛼𝑡12\displaystyle\frac{\beta(t)\alpha(t)}{\beta(t)+1}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\left(\frac{\sqrt{p_{k}(t)}|h_{k}(t)|}{\sqrt{\eta(t)\alpha(t)}}-1\right)^{2}}
+α​(t)β​(t)+1​(∑k∈𝒦pk​(t)​|hk​(t)|η​(t)​α​(t)−K)2+D​σn2η​(t).𝛼𝑡𝛽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝜂𝑡𝛼𝑡𝐾2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝜂𝑡\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha(t)}{\beta(t)+1}{\left(\frac{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\sqrt{p_{k}(t)}|h_{k}(t)|}{\sqrt{\eta(t)\alpha(t)}}-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta(t)}. (11)

It is seen from (11) that while the gradient MSN α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) appears linearly in the weights of both individual and composite misalignment errors, the gradient SMCV β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) plays a more distinguishing role in the MSE expression. In particular, when β​(t)→0→𝛽𝑡0\beta(t)\rightarrow 0, which could be the case when the model training just begins (as could be verified by Fig. 2, the individual signal misalignment error can be neglected. When β​(t)→∞→𝛽𝑡\beta(t)\rightarrow\infty, which could be the case when the model training converges or during the middle of the training when the dataset is highly non-IID (as could be verified by Fig. 2, the composite signal misalignment error disappears.

III Optimal Power Control with Known Gradient Statistics

In this section, we formulate and solve the optimal power control problem for minimizing MSE when the gradient statistics α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) are known. For convenience, we omit iteration index t𝑡t in this section. For each device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, we define its aggregation level with power p𝑝p and denoising factor η𝜂\eta as

Gk​(p,η)=pη​α​|hk|,subscript𝐺𝑘𝑝𝜂𝑝𝜂𝛼subscriptℎ𝑘G_{k}(p,\eta)=\sqrt{\frac{p}{\eta\alpha}}|h_{k}|, (12)

which represents the weight of the gradient from device k𝑘k in the global gradient aggregation (7)111The weight should be 1 for all devices in the ideal case.. Furthermore, we define aggregation capability of device k𝑘k as its aggregation level with peak power Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} and unit denoising factor η=1𝜂1\eta=1, i.e., Ck=Gk​(Pk,1)=Pkα​|hk|subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘1subscript𝑃𝑘𝛼subscriptℎ𝑘C_{k}=G_{k}(P_{k},1)=\sqrt{\frac{P_{k}}{\alpha}}|h_{k}|. Without loss of generality, we assume that

C1≤…≤Ck≤…≤CK.subscript𝐶1…subscript𝐶𝑘…subscript𝐶𝐾C_{1}\leq...\leq C_{k}\leq...\leq C_{K}. (13)

III-A Power Control Problem for General Case

In this subsection, we consider the optimal power control problem for MSE minimization in the general case. The problem is formulated as

𝒫1:min\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{1}:\quad\min\quad β​αβ+1​∑k∈𝒦(Gk​(pk,η)−1)2+αβ+1​(∑k∈𝒦Gk​(pk,η)−K)2+D​σn2η𝛽𝛼𝛽1subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂12𝛼𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂𝐾2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝜂\displaystyle\frac{\beta\alpha}{\beta+1}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\left(G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-1\right)^{2}}+\frac{\alpha}{\beta+1}{\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta} (14a)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle\mathnormal{s.t.}\quad 0≤pk≤Pk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequence0subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}0\leq p_{k}\leq P_{k},~{}~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K} (14b)

Different from the power control problem in [22], the objective function in (14a) contains not only the individual misalignment error (β​αβ+1​∑k∈𝒦(Gk​(pk,η)−1)2𝛽𝛼𝛽1subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂12\frac{\beta\alpha}{\beta+1}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{(G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-1)^{2}}), but also the composite misalignment error (αβ+1​(∑k∈𝒦Gk​(pk,η)−K)2𝛼𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂𝐾2\frac{\alpha}{\beta+1}{(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K)^{2}}). Problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is non-convex in general. Even if the denoising factor η𝜂\eta is given, problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is still hard to solve due to the coupling of each transmit power pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}. In the following, we present some properties of the optimal solution.

The optimal denoising factor η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} for problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} satisfies η∗≥C12superscript𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐶12\eta^{*}\geq C_{1}^{2}.

Proof:

Please refer to Appendix A. ∎

Lemma 1 reduces the range of η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} and shows that the optimal transmit power of the 111-st device is p1∗=P1subscriptsuperscript𝑝1subscript𝑃1p^{*}_{1}=P_{1}.

Lemma 2

The optimal power control policy satisfies pk∗=Pk,∀k∈{1,…,l}formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘1…𝑙p^{*}_{k}=P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{1,...,l\} and pk∗<Pk,∀k∈{l+1,…,K}formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘𝑙1…𝐾p^{*}_{k}<P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{l+1,...,K\} for some l∈𝒦𝑙𝒦l\in\mathcal{K}.

Proof:

Please refer to Appendix B. ∎

Based on Lemma 2, solving problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} can be equivalent to minimizing the objective function in the following K𝐾K exclusive subregions of the global power region, denoted as {ℳl}l∈𝒦subscriptsubscriptℳ𝑙𝑙𝒦\{\mathcal{M}_{l}\}_{l\in\mathcal{K}} and comparing their corresponding optimal solutions to obtain the global optimal solution:

ℳl={[p1,⋯,pK]∈ℝK|\displaystyle\mathcal{M}_{l}=\bigg{\{}[p_{1},\cdots,p_{K}]\in\mathbb{R}^{K}| pk=Pk,∀k∈{1,…,l},0≤pk<Pk,∀k∈{l+1,…,K}}.\displaystyle p_{k}=P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{1,...,l\},0\leq p_{k}<P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{l+1,...,K\}\bigg{\}}. (15)

To facilitate the derivation, we denote ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}} as a relaxed region of ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l} by removing the condition pk<Pksubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘p_{k}<P_{k}, for k∈{l+1,…,K}𝑘𝑙1…𝐾k\in\{l+1,...,K\}, i.e.,

ℳl~={[p1,⋯,pK]∈ℝK|\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}=\bigg{\{}[p_{1},\cdots,p_{K}]\in\mathbb{R}^{K}| pk=Pk,∀k∈{1,…,l},pk≥0,∀k∈{l+1,…,K}}.\displaystyle p_{k}=P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{1,...,l\},p_{k}\geq 0,\forall{k}\in\{l+1,...,K\}\bigg{\}}. (16)

For the sub-problem defined in each relaxed subregion ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}, for l∈𝒦𝑙𝒦l\in\mathcal{K}, taking the derivative of the objective function (14a) w.r.t. pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} and equating it to zero for all k∈{l+1,…,K}𝑘𝑙1…𝐾k\in\{l+1,...,K\}, we obtain the optimal transmit power p~l,k∗subscriptsuperscript~𝑝𝑙𝑘\tilde{p}^{*}_{l,k} at any given η𝜂\eta as

p~l,k∗=[β+K−∑i=1lGi​(Pi,η)β+K−l]2⋅α​η|hk|2,k∈{l+1,…,K}.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript~𝑝𝑙𝑘⋅superscriptdelimited-[]𝛽𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑙subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝜂𝛽𝐾𝑙2𝛼𝜂superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2𝑘𝑙1…𝐾\tilde{p}^{*}_{l,k}=\left[\frac{\beta+K-\sum_{i=1}^{l}{G_{i}(P_{i},\eta)}}{\beta+K-l}\right]^{2}\cdot\frac{\alpha\eta}{|h_{k}|^{2}},k\in\{l+1,...,K\}. (17)

G0​(l)=β+K−1η​∑i=1lCiβ+K−l.subscript𝐺0𝑙𝛽𝐾1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑙subscript𝐶𝑖𝛽𝐾𝑙\displaystyle G_{0}(l)=\frac{\beta+K-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\eta}}\sum_{i=1}^{l}{C_{i}}}{\beta+K-l}. (18)

Lemma 3

Proof:

Please refer to Appendix C. ∎

Lemma 3 shows that only the transmit power vectors 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscript~𝒑𝑙\tilde{\bm{p}}^{*}_{l}’s with elements satisfying p~l,k∗<Pk,∀k∈{l+1,…,K}formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript~𝑝𝑙𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘𝑙1…𝐾\tilde{p}^{*}_{l,k}<P_{k},\forall{k}\in\{l+1,...,K\} are legal candidates of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}. Remark 1

Theorem 1 shows that these devices k∈{1,…,l∗}𝑘1…superscript𝑙k\in\{1,...,l^{*}\} with aggregation capability not higher than that of device l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} should transmit their gradients with full power, i.e., pk=Pksubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘p_{k}=P_{k}, while devices k∈{l∗+1,…,K}𝑘superscript𝑙1…𝐾k\in\{l^{*}+1,...,K\} with aggregation capability higher than that of device l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} should transmit with the power so that they have the same aggregation level, given by

G0∗=β+K−∑i=1l∗Gi​(Pi,η∗)β+K−l∗,subscriptsuperscript𝐺0𝛽𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝑙subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖superscript𝜂𝛽𝐾superscript𝑙\displaystyle G^{*}_{0}=\frac{\beta+K-\sum_{i=1}^{l^{*}}{G_{i}(P_{i},\eta^{*})}}{\beta+K-l^{*}}, (23)

somewhat analogous to channel inversion.

III-B On The Optimal Transmit Power Function

In this subsection, we analyse the optimal transmit power 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} as a vector function of the gradient MSN α𝛼\alpha, the gradient SMCV β𝛽\beta and the noise variance σn2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\sigma^{2}_{n}, i.e., 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)=[p1∗​(α,β,σn2),…,pK∗​(α,β,σn2)]superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝1𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐾𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n})=[p^{*}_{1}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}),...,p^{*}_{K}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n})]. Note that the vector function 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) might have abrupt changes at some (α,β,σn2)𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) due to the discrete nature of the optimal device threshold l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} in Theorem 1. In this work, however, we can show that 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) is continuous222𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) is a continuous vector-valued function if and only if each element pk∗​(α,β,σn2)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛p^{*}_{k}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}), for k∈{1,…,K}𝑘1…𝐾k\in\{1,...,K\} is a continuous function. everywhere for all (α≥0,β≥0,σn2≥0)formulae-sequence𝛼0formulae-sequence𝛽0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛0(\alpha\geq 0,\beta\geq 0,\sigma^{2}_{n}\geq 0). Denote 𝒳l⊆ℝ3subscript𝒳𝑙superscriptℝ3\mathcal{X}_{l}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{3} as the domain of the vector function 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) when 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) lies in the subregion ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}, for l∈𝒦𝑙𝒦l\in\mathcal{K}. Finally, we can formally conclude the following property of the optimal transmit power function with respect to the gradient statistics and noise variance.

Property 1

The optimal transmit power 𝐩∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝐩𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is a continuous and monotonic vector function in the entire domain of (α≥0,β≥0,σn2≥0)formulae-sequence𝛼0formulae-sequence𝛽0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛0(\alpha\geq 0,\beta\geq 0,\sigma^{2}_{n}\geq 0). Moreover, it decreases with β𝛽\beta, increases with σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\sigma_{n}^{2}, and remain unchanged w.r.t. α𝛼\alpha.

Take a system with K=6𝐾6K=6 devices for illustration. Fig. 3 shows the optimal transmit power of each device pk∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘p^{*}_{k} as a function of gradient SMCV β𝛽\beta, together with the corresponding optimal index l∗superscript𝑙l^{*}. The results are based on one channel realization of each device, |hk|subscriptℎ𝑘|h_{k}|, taken independently from normalized Rayleigh distribution, given by [0.50,0.82,0.85,1.16,2.09,2.83]0.500.820.851.162.092.83[0.50,0.82,0.85,1.16,2.09,2.83]. The peak power constraint of each device is set to be same, resulting in the same average received SNR, given by PkD​σn2=5 dB and 10 dBsubscript𝑃𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛25 dB and 10 dB\frac{P_{k}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}=\mbox{5 dB and 10 dB}, respectively. The gradient MSN α=0.25𝛼0.25\alpha=0.25, noise variance σ2=1superscript𝜎21\sigma^{2}=1 and D=1𝐷1D=1. Fig. 3 clearly verifies that the optimal transmit power 𝒑∗​(α,β,σn2)superscript𝒑𝛼𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) is a continuous and monotonically decreasing vector function of the gradient SMCV β𝛽\beta. In particular, it is seen that when β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0, all the devices transmit with full power; when beta increases, the power of the devices with large aggregation capability decreases, then gradually approaches a constant, and the larger the aggregation capability is, the smaller the constant transmit power is. In addition, it is observed from Fig. 3 that when the peak power budget increases, more devices can transmit with less power than its peak value. Equivalently, the optimal transmit power decreases when the noise variance decreases.

III-C Power Control Problem for Special Cases

In this subsection, we show that the threshold-based power control in [22] and the full power transmission are two special cases of the optimal power control policy where the gradient SMCV β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty and β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0, respectively.

III-C1 β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty

As discussed in Section II-D, this case may happen when the model training converges and/or the dataset is highly non-IID. In this case, the problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} reduces to the power control problem in [22]. The optimal solution when β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty can be reduced directly from the solution of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}. Specifically, by letting β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty in Theorem 1, we have the following Corollary,

Corollary 1

The optimal transmit power when β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty has a threshold-based structure, i.e.,

pk∗={Pk,∀k∈{1,…,l∗}α​η∗|hk|2,∀k∈{l∗+1,…,K},superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘casessubscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘1…superscript𝑙𝛼superscript𝜂superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2for-all𝑘superscript𝑙1…𝐾p_{k}^{*}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}P_{k},&\forall{k}\in\{1,...,l^{*}\}\\ \frac{\alpha\eta^{*}}{|h_{k}|^{2}},&\forall{k}\in\{l^{*}+1,...,K\},\end{array}\right. (24)

where the optimal denoising factor is given as

η∗=(α​∑i=1l∗Ci2+D​σn2α​∑i=1l∗Ci)2,superscript𝜂superscript𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝑙subscript𝐶𝑖2\displaystyle\eta^{*}=\bigg{(}\frac{\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{l^{*}}{C_{i}^{2}}+D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{l^{*}}{C_{i}}}\bigg{)}^{2}, (25)

and l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} is given in (20).

Note that the optimal denoising factor η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} when β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty can be interpreted as the threshold, since whether a device transmits with full power or not depends entirely on the comparison between its aggregation capability Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and η∗superscript𝜂\sqrt{\eta^{*}}. Nevertheless, such threshold interpretation of η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} does not hold for problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} with general β𝛽\beta.

III-C2 β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0

As discussed in Section II-D, β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 could happen when the model training just begins and the dataset is IID. In this case, the individual signal misalignment error disappears in the MSE expressions. The original MSE expression reduces to α​(∑k∈𝒦Gk​(pk,η)−K)2+D​σn2η𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂𝐾2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝜂\alpha{\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta}. Note that the optimal solution when β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 cannot be reduced directly from Theorem 1 by simply letting β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 as l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} is unknown.

Corollary 2

The optimal transmit power when β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 is full power transmission, i.e.,

pk∗=Pk,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle p_{k}^{*}=P_{k},~{}~{}~{}\forall{k}\in\mathcal{K}, (26)

and the optimal denoising factor is given by

η∗=(α​(∑i∈𝒦Ci)2+D​σn2α​K​∑i∈𝒦Ci)2.superscript𝜂superscript𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖𝒦subscript𝐶𝑖2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝛼𝐾subscript𝑖𝒦subscript𝐶𝑖2\displaystyle\eta^{*}=\bigg{(}\frac{\alpha\big{(}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{i}}\big{)}^{2}+D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\alpha K\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{i}}}\bigg{)}^{2}. (27)
Proof:

It is obvious that the optimal denoising factor satisfies η∗≥∑k∈𝒦Cksuperscript𝜂subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐶𝑘\eta^{*}\geq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{k}}. For any denoising factor η≥1K2​(∑k∈𝒦Ck)2𝜂1superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐶𝑘2\eta\geq\frac{1}{K^{2}}\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{k}}\right)^{2}, it must hold that ∑k∈𝒦Gk​(pk,η)≤Ksubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂𝐾\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)\leq K when β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0. Therefore, for minimizing the composite signal misalignment error (∑k∈𝒦Gk​(pk,η)−K)2superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝜂𝐾2\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}, all the devices should transmit with full power, i.e., pk∗=Pk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦p_{k}^{*}=P_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. The MSE expression α​(∑k∈𝒦Gk​(Pk,η)−K)2+D​σn2η𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘𝜂𝐾2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝜂\alpha{\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(P_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta} is a unary quadratic function about 1η1𝜂\frac{1}{\sqrt{\eta}}, thus it is easy to derive the optimal solution (27) in closed form. Corollary 2 is thus proven. ∎

Note that l∗=Ksuperscript𝑙𝐾l^{*}=K when β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 based on the proof. The direction of the gradient vector received from each device at the edge server is independent to the power of the transmitting device. Thus, increasing the power of all devices can reduce the noise-induced error when the composite signal misalignment error is fixed.

Remark 2

The threshold-based power control in [22] and the full power transmission are sub-optimal in general and they are optimal only when β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty and β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0, respectively. In particular, the threshold-based power control can only perform efficiently when the model training converges and the dataset is highly non-IID, the full power transmission can only perform efficiently when the model training just begins and the dataset is IID. Compared with these two schemes, our proposed power control policy is always optimal. These findings shall be validated via experimental results in Section V.

IV Adaptive Power Control with Unknown Gradient Statistics

In this section, we consider the practical scenario where the gradient statistics α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) are unknown. We propose a method to estimate α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) in each time block and then devise an adaptive power control scheme based on the optimal solution of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} by using the estimated α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t).

IV-A Parameters Estimation

In this subsection, we propose a method to estimate α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) at each time block t𝑡t directly based on their definitions in (9) and (10), respectively.

IV-A1 Estimation of α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t)

Let Bk​(t)≜‖𝒈k​(t)‖≜subscript𝐵𝑘𝑡normsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡B_{k}(t)\triangleq\|\bm{g}_{k}(t)\| denote the gradient norm of device k𝑘k at iteration t𝑡t. At the end of each round of local training, we let each device transmit its gradient norm Bk​(t)subscript𝐵𝑘𝑡B_{k}(t) to the edge server before sending the gradient vector 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t). Note that the communication cost of transmitting Bk​(t)subscript𝐵𝑘𝑡B_{k}(t) is negligible compared with that of transmitting the gradient 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t). This is because the gradient norm Bk​(t)subscript𝐵𝑘𝑡B_{k}(t) is a scalar while the gradient 𝒈k​(t)subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}(t) is a vector whose dimension D𝐷D can be very large333In the considered datasets for experimental validation, D𝐷D is in the order of 104superscript10410^{4}.. By definition (9), we can estimate the gradient MSN as the mean of the squared gradient norms across all the participating devices:

α^​(t)=1K​∑k∈𝒦Bk2​(t).^𝛼𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2𝑡\hat{\alpha}(t)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{B_{k}^{2}(t)}. (28)

IV-A2 Estimation of β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t)

By definition in (10), the gradient SMCV β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) depends on md​(t)subscript𝑚𝑑𝑡m_{d}(t) and σd​(t)subscript𝜎𝑑𝑡\sigma_{d}(t). Before each device sending its gradient at time block t𝑡t, we cannot estimate β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) in advance. However, from the experimental results of real datasets in Fig. 2, it can be observed that β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) is highly correlated among adjacent iterations. Thus we propose to estimate β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) using the aggregated gradient at time block t−1𝑡1t-1 as below

β^​(t)=α^​(t−1)−∑d=1Dg^d2​(t−1)∑d=1Dg^d2​(t−1),^𝛽𝑡^𝛼𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑑2𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷superscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑑2𝑡1\hat{\beta}(t)=\frac{\hat{\alpha}(t-1)-\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)}}{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)}}, (29)

where α^​(t−1)^𝛼𝑡1\hat{\alpha}(t-1) estimates ∑dσd2​(t−1)+md2​(t−1)subscript𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡1\sum_{d}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t-1)+m_{d}^{2}(t-1)} and ∑dg^d2​(t−1)subscript𝑑superscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑑2𝑡1\sum_{d}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)} estimates ∑dmd2​(t−1)subscript𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑑2𝑡1\sum_{d}{m_{d}^{2}(t-1)}.

IV-B FL with Adaptive Power Control

In this subsection, we propose the FL process with adaptive power control, which is presented in Algorithm 1. The algorithm has three steps. First, each device locally takes one step of SGD on the current model using its local dataset (line 5). After that each device calculates the norm of its local gradient and uploads it to the edge server with conventional digital transmission (line 6 and line 7). Second, the edge server estimates parameters α​(t)𝛼𝑡\alpha(t) and β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) based on the received gradient norm at time block t𝑡t and historical aggregated gradient (line 9 and line 16). Then the optimal transmit power and denoising factor are obtained based on (21) and (22), respectively (line 10). Third, the edge server informs the optimal transmit power to each device and each device transmits local gradient with the assigned power simultaneously using AirComp to the edge server in an analog manner (line 12-14).

Note that the computational complexity of finding the optimal power control in Algorithm 1 mainly consists of the time complexity of sorting devices by aggregation capability, which is O​(K​log⁡K)𝑂𝐾𝐾O(K\log{K}), and the time complexity of finding l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} by Lemma 4, which is O​(K)𝑂𝐾O(K). It is approximately the same as the existing scheme [22]. The additional overhead introduced by our method when compared with [22] lies at the communication cost for each device to send the gradient norm Bk​(t)subscript𝐵𝑘𝑡B_{k}(t) to the edge server as shown in line 7 of Algorithm 1, which is negligible as discussed in Section IV-A.

V Experimental Results

In this section, we provide experimental results to validate the performance of the proposed power control for AirComp-based FL over fading channels.

V-A Experiment Setup

We conducted experiments on a simulated environment where the number of edge devices is K=10𝐾10K=10 if not specified otherwise. The wireless channels from each device to the edge server follow IID Rayleigh fading, such that hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}’s are modeled as IID complex Gaussian variables with zero mean and unit variance. For each device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, we define SNRk=𝔼​[Pk​|hk|2D​σn2]=PkD​σn2subscriptSNR𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2subscript𝑃𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\mbox{SNR}_{k}=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{P_{k}|h_{k}|^{2}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}\right]=\frac{P_{k}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}} as the average received SNR.

V-A1 Baselines

We compare the proposed adaptive power control scheme with the following baseline approaches:

  • •

    Error-free transmission: the aggregated gradient is updated perfectly without any transmission error. This is equivalent to the centralized SGD algorithm.

  • •

    Power control with known statistics: We assume that the gradient statistics are known in advance at the beginning of the training, and then apply the proposed power control. In our experiments, the actual gradient statistics are obtained from 100010001000 gradient samples without transmission error.

  • •

    Threshold-based power control in [22]: this is the power control scheme given in [22], which assumed that signals are normalized. Note that it is actually the special case of our proposed power control scheme with β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty by considering the individual misalignment error only in problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}.

  • •

    Full power transmission: all devices transmit with full power Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} and the edge server applies the optimal denoising factor in (22), where l∗=Ksuperscript𝑙𝐾l^{*}=K.

V-A2 Datasets

We evaluate the training of convolutional neural network on three datasets: MNIST, CIFAR-10 and SVHN. MNIST dataset consists of 10 categories ranging from digit 0 to 9 and a total of 70000 labeled data samples (60000 for training and 10000 for testing). CIFAR-10 dataset includes 60000 color images (50000 for training and 10000 for testing) of 10 different types of objects. SVHN is a real-world image dataset for developing machine learning and object recognition algorithms with minimal requirement on data preprocessing and formatting, which includes 99289 labeled data samples (73257 for training and 26032 for testing).

V-A3 Data Distribution

To study the impact of the SMCV of gradient β𝛽\beta for optimal transmit power, we simulate two types of dataset partitions among the mobile devices, i.e., the IID setting and non-IID one. For the former, we randomly partition the training samples into 100100100 equal shards, each of which is assigned to one particular device. While for the latter, we first sort the data by digit label, divide it into 200200200 equal shards, and randomly assign 222 shards to each device.

V-A4 Neural network and hyper-parameters

In all our experiments, we adopt the convolutional neural network (the number of layers is 11). The hyper-parameters are set as follows: momentum optimizer is 0.5, the number of local updates between two global aggregations is 1, local batch size is 10 and learning rate γ=0.01𝛾0.01\gamma=0.01.

V-B Experimental Results

Fig. 4 compares the test accuracy for the three considered datasets with IID dataset partition and non-IID dataset partition, respectively, where the average received SNR is set as 10 dB for all devices. It is observed that the performance gap to the scheme with known gradient statistics is very small, which indicates the proposed methods for estimating gradient statistics are effective. It is also observed that the model accuracy of the proposed power control scheme is better than threshold-based power control and full power transmission. From Fig. 2, we have known that the averaged gradient SMCV β​(t)𝛽𝑡\beta(t) in the IID dataset partition is less than that in the non-IID dataset partition and it increases over iterations. Threshold-based power control suffers significant accuracy loss in the IID partition or at the beginning of training. This is because in this case, the gradient SMCV is small and thus the MSE is dominated by the composite misalignment error. As a result, threshold-based power control that considers the individual misalignment error only is much inferior. Besides, full power transmission suffers significant accuracy loss in the non-IID partition or at the end of training. This is because the gradient SMCV is large and therefore the full power transmission scheme fails to minimize the individual misalignment error that dominates the MSE in this case.

Fig. 5 illustrates the test accuracy for MNIST with non-IID data partition at the average received SNR=5 dBSNR5 dB\mbox{SNR}=\mbox{5 dB}. It is observed that the overall performance of the proposed scheme is still better than two baseline approaches at low SNR region. In specific, full power transmission performs better than threshold-based power control scheme. This is mainly because when the noise variance is large, full power transmission can strongly suppress noise error that dominates the MSE.

Finally, Fig. 6 compares the test accuracy of different power control schemes at varying number of devices K𝐾K. Here, MNIST dataset with non-IID partition is used, the average received SNR of all the devices is set as SNRk=10subscriptSNR𝑘10\mbox{SNR}_{k}=10 dB and the results are averaged over 505050 model trainings. First, it is observed that the test accuracy achieved by all the four schemes increases when the number of participating devices K𝐾K increases but cannot increase further when K𝐾K is large enough. In particular, the test accuracy of all the considered schemes keeps unchanged when K≥30𝐾30K\geq 30, due to the fact that the edge server can aggregate enough data for averaging. Second, the proposed scheme outperforms both of threshold-based power control and full power transmission throughout the whole regime of K𝐾K. Full power transmission approaches threshold-based power control when K𝐾K is small (i.e., K=4𝐾4K=4 in Fig. 6), but the performance compromises as K𝐾K increases, due to the lack of power adaptation to reduce the misalignment error.

VI Conclusion

This work studied the power control optimization problem for the over-the-air federated learning over fading channels by taking the gradient statistics into account. The optimal power control policy is derived in closed form when the first- and second-order gradient statistics are known. It is shown that the optimal transmit power on each device decreases with gradient SMCV and increases with noise variance. In the special cases where β𝛽\beta approaches infinity and zero, the optimal transmit power reduces to threshold-based power control and full power transmission, respectively. We propose an adaptive power control algorithm that dynamically adjusts the transmit power in each iteration based on the estimation results. Experimental results show that our proposed adaptive power control scheme outperforms the existing schemes. In the future work, we can further exploit the gradient statistics for joint power control and beamforming when each edge device has multiple antennas.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma 1

We prove this Lemma by contradiction. Suppose the optimal denoising factor η∗≤C12superscript𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐶12\eta^{*}\leq C_{1}^{2}. Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3

To prove this lemma is equal to proving that if the optimal solution 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} of the sub-problem defined in the relaxed subregion ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}} does not lie in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}, the global optimal solution p∗superscript𝑝p^{*} of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} must not lie in subregion ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}. First, we prove that 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only local minimum point in ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. Note that the derivative of a differentiable function at the local minimum point must be 0, and 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only zero point of the derivative of (14a) w.r.t. pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}. Hence, 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only local minimum point in ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. Now, we prove Lemma 3 by contradiction. We assume that 𝒑~l∗∉ℳlsubscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙subscriptℳ𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l}\notin\mathcal{M}_{l}, then there is no local minimum point in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l} due to ℳl⊆ℳl~subscriptℳ𝑙~subscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}\subseteq\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. If 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} lies in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}, 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} must be a local minimum point due to the fact that 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} is the minimum point in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l} and 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} is an interior point of ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}. It contradicts that there is no local minimum point in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}. Therefore, if 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} does not lie in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}, the global optimal transmit power 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} must not lie in the l𝑙l-th subregion ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}. The proof of Lemma 3 is completed.

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 1

To complete the proof, we need to show that with l∗superscript𝑙l^{*} defined in (20), the optimal transmit power is 𝒑~l∗∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑superscript𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l^{*}} in the l∗superscript𝑙l^{*}-th relaxed subregion ℳl∗~~subscriptℳsuperscript𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l^{*}}}. Lemma 3 shows that ∀l∈𝒦for-all𝑙𝒦\forall l\in\mathcal{K}, if 𝒑~l∗∉ℳlsubscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙subscriptℳ𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l}\notin\mathcal{M}_{l}, the optimal transmit power 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} must not lie in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}. By definition of ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, ∀l∈𝒦∖ℒfor-all𝑙𝒦ℒ\forall l\in\mathcal{K}\setminus\mathcal{L}, 𝒑~l∗∉ℳlsubscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙subscriptℳ𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l}\notin\mathcal{M}_{l}. Hence, 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} must lie in ⋃l∈ℒℳlsubscript𝑙ℒsubscriptℳ𝑙\bigcup_{l\in\mathcal{L}}{\mathcal{M}_{l}}, i.e.,

MSE​(𝒑∗)=min𝒑∈⋃l∈ℒℳl⁡MSE​(𝒑).MSEsuperscript𝒑subscript𝒑subscript𝑙ℒsubscriptℳ𝑙MSE𝒑\displaystyle\mbox{MSE}(\bm{p}^{*})=\min_{\bm{p}\in\bigcup_{l\in\mathcal{L}}{\mathcal{M}_{l}}}{\mbox{MSE}(\bm{p})}. (32)

For all l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L}, 𝒑~l∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the minimum point in ℳl~~subscriptℳ𝑙\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}, and it is also the minimum point in ℳlsubscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l} due to 𝒑~l∗∈ℳlsubscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑𝑙subscriptℳ𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l}\in\mathcal{M}_{l} and ℳl⊆ℳl~subscriptℳ𝑙~subscriptℳ𝑙\mathcal{M}_{l}\subseteq\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}, i.e.,

Substituting (33) back to (32), we have

Therefore, the candidate transmit power 𝒑~l∗∗subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒑superscript𝑙\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l^{*}} with the smallest value Vl∗subscript𝑉superscript𝑙V_{l^{*}} is the optimal transmit power of the problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}. According to (17) and (19), the optimal transmit power and denoising factor are the forms given in Theorem 1.

Appendix F Proof of Lemma 5

Based on (17) and (19), we have

We complete the proof of Lemma 5.
